awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Electrocatalysis Modulated by Bifunctional Organic Monolayer: CO2 Reduction to C2
awd_abstract_narration:
This Early-concept Grant for Exploratory Research (EAGER) provides proof-of-concept data for a novel technology supporting our nation’s transition to clean energy.  Part of the clean energy equation involves the capture and conversion of carbon dioxide (CO2) produced from the combustion of fossil resources.  The project further supports progress towards low carbon emission chemical manufacturing by exploring electrochemical conversion of CO2 to small building-block molecules used widely in the manufacture of a broad range of chemical and fuel products.  The study focuses on novel catalyst designs that promote highly localized electric fields, thus potentially enabling more efficient energy utilization and greater CO2 conversion efficiency than obtained with conventional catalyst designs.  The project also incorporates clean-energy related educational and outreach activities targeted at both pre-college and college level students. 

A high electric field can rearrange the electronic orbitals of chemical species and alter the electronic interactions between adsorbates and catalytic surfaces. This influences the thermodynamics, kinetics, and mechanisms of (electro)catalytic reactions. The project investigates the effects of local electric fields and exposed-surface sites on the CO2 electroreduction reaction (CO2RR) to C2 products.  The concept is investigated using a combination of atomic-scale simulations, electrocatalyst synthesis, spectroscopic characterization, and electrocatalytic performance testing. The catalyst is prepared from a bifunctional thiol-based monolayer (e.g., -S-CnH2n-NH2) immobilized onto a Cu nanowire (NW) array. This catalytic structure enhances local electric fields due to opposing charges in the head and tail functional groups of the monolayer. Surface coverage of thiol molecules is simultaneously tuned to expose Cu step and defect sites.  Effectiveness of the combined approach for accelerating CO2RR-to-C2 will be evaluated by (1) deriving relationships between thiol composition/structure and local field strength, (2) determining the thiol surface coverage effects on exposed Cu sites, and (3) investigating the performance and stability of the bifunctional organic monolayer modified Cu NWs under reaction conditions. In parallel with the research, the investigators will involve both graduate students and undergraduate students in their research, and participate in the Immersive Scholar Program at UMass Lowell to promote undergraduate research, including women and underrepresented minorities. The investigators will also convey the importance of clean energy technology and modular electrocatalysis into outreach activities for K-9 students and distribution via various educational media.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
This NSF EAGER project aims to examine the bifunctional organic monolayer-modified copper nanowires (NWs) featuring both organic and inorganic active sites, exposed-surface sites, and local surface electronic properties. This research specifically focuses on the application of these nanowires in the selective reactive capture of carbon dioxide (CO2) and its subsequential reduction reaction (CO2RR) to C2 products, namely ethylene and ethanol, which are economically more valuable than other products of CO2 reduction.

 

One major outcome of this project is to examine the correlations between organic ligand surface coverage, ligand configuration, the stability and catalytic performance of copper-based nanoparticle and nanowires for electrocatalysis. Our theoretical study affirms the catalyst can be stabilized by the self-assembled monolayer of the organic ligands (e.g., aminothiolates) under electrochemical conditions. As for the CO2RR performance, the ligand-metal interface improves the activity of CO2RR by forming the strong N-C bond from the amine group within the ligand. The selectivity of multi-carbon products (i.e., C-C coupling) is enhanced by lowering the activation barriers, through: (1) dual organic (N) and inorganic surface sites (Cu) at a low ligand coverage; (2) strong C-N bond and H bond stabilizing the final product of C-C coupling at a high ligand coverage; (3) ligand-induced lateral interaction suppressing hydrogen evolution reaction over the ligand-metal interface at a high ligand coverage. The corresponding experiments further validated the existence of thiolate-type Cu-S bond before and after CO2RR using X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy spectra. The simulation conclusion was observed in experiment study where both the selectivity and partial current density of C2+ products over the coated Cu catalysts enhanced by 1.5-fold, and 2-fold, respectively.

 

Another major outcome of this project resides on the training and mentoring of graduate and undergraduate researchers (e.g., female) for the next-generation workforce. In particular, the project supported two Ph.D. students, who were successfully defended their thesis at the end of the project. One Ph.D. student (under PI Che, theory) has obtained North American Catalysis Meeting Kokes award, AICHE Catalysis Reaction Engineering travel award, the 2024 Outstanding Graduate Student award in Chemical Engineering department at UMass Lowell. The Ph.D. student (under PI Che, theory), after graduation, became a tenure-track Assistant Professor. The undergraduate student (under PI Che, theory) has successfully graduated at the end of the project as B.S. in Chemical Engineering department at UMass Lowell and has been recruited to work in National Energy Technology Laboratory in summer 2024 as Mickey Leland Energy Fellow.

 

The intellectual merits of this project include novel catalyst designs that promote dual active sites (i.e., amine of aminothiolates, Cu), potentially improving CO2 reactive capture and conversion efficiency, the developed DFT and kinetic model for graduate teaching project materials. Such achievements yield new types of metallic surfaces with self-assembled monolayers for mitigating climate change via CO2 capture and conversion.

The integration of ab-initio modeling, kinetic model, experimental material synthesis and characterization, and electrocatalysis performance, offers exceptional possibilities to facilitate materials development and create the opportunity to enter a new paradigm in catalyst design based on fundamentals and materials data rather than trial-and-error.

 


Last Modified: 05/21/2024
Modified by: Fanglin Che
